newsitem.title: DENMARK: U.S. data send Danish share prices down.
newsitem.headline: U.S. data send Danish share prices down.

text.p: A spate of U.S. indicators and local profit-taking sent Danish share prices down on Tuesday, ending a four-day run of record highs.
"We expect the market to fall further tomorrow. The American numbers sent US and German bonds down and that spilled over into the stock market," a Copenhagen dealer said.
"The Danish market has risen sharply over the past week and that has given rise to profit-taking. We expect that to continue over the next few days," he added.
The KFX top-20 index closed 0.53 point down, at 170.94, in overall bourse turnover of 1.2 billion crowns.
Its June future fell 0.55, to 171.20, with 1,837 contracts each worth 100,000 crowns traded.
Movement was spread fairly evenly across the top 20, with seven shares up, eight down and five unchanged.

The largest movment was a three percent rise by chemicals group Superfos, to 166.00 crowns, on technical trading after breaking the 160-crown resistance point on Monday, the dealer said, adding that prices in general were likely to slip as the summer holiday season arrived.
"We are entering a news-starved period," he said. --Steve Weizman, Copenhagen newsroom +45 33969650
